title: Do people who buy drones often break them pretty quickly? How does the drone industry deal with this problem? - Quora

response.answer_text: I flew my first drone into a waterfall — it was never to be found again. It was a Phantom 4 and I thought that I could skilfully navigate up and around several cliffs, rocks, and splashing water using only my iPad screen as navigation. Unfortunately, the Phantom 4 does not have sensors at the top of the drone so it got caught in a wire overhead. You may ask what the hell a wire is doing around a waterfall — good question. I really don’t know. I searched and searched for my Phantom to no avail. I concluded that it was perhaps sandwiched in between some unreachable crevice of rocks or fell into the abyss of the lower pool of the waterfall…Fortunately I was able to salvage the footage as a lower quality version of my videos automatically save on the DJI Go app. This provided some needed closure for my loss. I learned my lesson after that…kind of. Since then, I’ve crashed my drone twice (DJI Mavic). Both times I was trying out new features and wasn’t in a totally open space, which was fault. Multiple lessons learned there but fortunately the damage was not fatal, and I was able to repair my drone. To answer your question more directly, there are a couple of strategies I see used to address the problem and likelihood of crashing if you’re using it frequently: Insurance: DJI for example has one year warranties on their drones. There is also an extra insurance package you can purchase separately that reimburses you on the total cost of your repairs for that year. DJI also has several training centers setup globally that allow you to learn and practice flying drones, so they’re working hard to provide a safe environment for people. Sensors: Every drone that DJI releases is getting better and better with upgraded sensor and safety technology. Currently you have to purchase something like the DJI Inspire to get truly awesome sensors, but the price is out of range for most people and it’s more of a professional tool. Even then, there is yet to be a true 360 degree sensor for a drone…one that’s affordable, anyways. I think the next step is integrating this into future drone releases — pretty much making the skill of being a drone “pilot” virtually risk-free (and easy).

I’ve been flying drones for several years now. Cheap (under $100) drones would crash all the time, but I never had any damage because they were very light weight. When I moved on to more expensive drones like the Phantom 2, Phantom 3 and now Mavic I have a much more reliable vehicle. True, with the extra weight and more expensive hardware, they are subject to damage in a crash. BUT in the last 3 years, I’ve had a total of one crash, and that was putting a Phantom into a tree (no damage other than pine needle stains on my blades). Simply put, these vehicles don’t crash unless you are pushing the limits of the vehicle (example, racing a drone). None the less, the industry is trying to address the issue. For example, DJI, the maker of the Phantom and Mavic have an insurance plan for crashed vehicles. Personally, I think it is not worth the money (i.e. cost vs probability of using the insurance), but I think that is going to vary with the individual.

I have 3 quadcopters, all working, ranging from a mini (25cm square) to medium (75cm square) from 1 to 6 years old. They’ve all had crashes, trees and hard landings, or flips at low altitude, silly things indoors and after hundreds of flights, my total damage is one prop on the smallest. They’re easy to fly, and unlike planes can be stabilised quickly by “hands off”. Learning to control altitude gently is the most essential skill. A few dozen indoor test flights, with control within floor and ceiling, or outdoors using a football or rugby goal as a reference, is all you need. 1 to 3 hours, and you’ll recover from anything. My background from park flyer planes helps a little with input control, but drones are way easier to fly.

“Do people who buy drones often break them pretty quickly? How does the drone industry deal with this problem?” They sell spare parts at a reasonable price. Shell, props, prop guards, landing gears etc., or complete “crash kits”. If you manage to break the camera gimbal, that’s more expensive. The electronics and the motors are very hard to damage. There are fragile and very durable quadcopters too. Flying into a concrete building with 80..100 km/h is fatal for almost all of them. Small accidents happen, but a chipped prop is not a big deal.

Sorry you crashed your drone. I don’t have a drone and I am not aware of knowing anyone who does, but I spent many years building model airplanes, so I can state confidently that the answer to your first question is Yes. As to the second question, I am positive that the drone industry is absolutely delighted with this situation and is praying that it doesn’t change. Trouble is, sensible laws are starting to get in the way. Better get your new drone while you still can!

The drone industry couldn't care less. If anything, you will buy another drone and put more dollars in their pocket. Most crashes occur due to human error or some bad luck, therefore the industry is not responsible for that. I never crashed my DJI Phantom 4, though i did have several near misses. I'm sure i would eventually crash it if i didn't sell it last year. It's just something one has to live with.

They keep making money. The spare parts market seems to be the way they deal with the issue. I imagine there is also an insurance market of some sort, but I don’t see how that could work given that drone skills could potentially be all over the map. If you have a broken drone, you might consider Googling “drone repair” or “drone repair in (insert your city or nearby city)” On the consumer side, its smart to find a field that’s suitable for drone flight and practice. Also, it might be smart to Google “learn how to fly a drone.” Also, I’m sure that there is a local or semi-local Meetup group around drones. So hopping on Meetup can be helpful.
